nodes.title: Shape: Talking about Seeing and Doing (2006)
nodes.label: Shape: Talking about Seeing and Doing
nodes.author: George Stiny
nodes.synopsis: A monograph on the subject of shape grammars. The book is dedicated to showing how visual calculating in shape grammars includes symbolic calculating in classical computing machines and how in this way it broadens calculating to include art and design.

nodes.title: The Sciences of the Artificial. 3rd Edition (1996)
nodes.label: The Sciences of the Artificial
nodes.author: Herbert A. Simon
nodes.synopsis: A seminal book on design and artificial intelligence. Among other important ideas, it includes Simon's educational programme, 'The Science of Design,' aimed at incorporating problem-solving tools from artificial intelligence as aids to the design process.

nodes.title: Computation: Finite and Infinite Machines (1967)
nodes.label: Computation: Finite and Infinite Machines
nodes.author: Marvin L. Minsky
nodes.synopsis: One of the best early books on abstract models of computation, based on lecture notes from classes taught by Minsky at MIT. One of the interesting aspects of the book is the in-depth discussion of how different models of computation are connected, such as the relation of finite automata to neural networks, of Turing machines to recursive functions, of digital computers to register machines.

nodes.title: A History of Modern Computing, 2nd Edition (1998)
nodes.label: A History of Modern Computing
nodes.author: Paul E. Ceruzzi
nodes.synopsis: A great book on the history of digital computers. Extensive analyses of the different developments in hardware and software from the 1940s to early 2000s, providing insight into the corporate, cultural, and social environment surrounding them.

nodes.title: Structural Information Theory: the simplicity of visual form (2012)
nodes.label: Structural Information Theory
nodes.author: Emanuel L. J. Leeuwenberg and Peter A. van der Helm
nodes.synopsis: This book covers in a comprehensive way 'structural information theory', a theory about the way the human visual system organizes a raw visual stimulus into objects and object parts. The focus is on representations of the higher-level outcomes of the perceptual process as opposed to process mechanisms at a lower neuro-cognitive level.

nodes.title: Linear Algebra and Learning from Data (2019)
nodes.label: Linear Algebra and Learning from Data
nodes.author: Gilbert Strang
nodes.synopsis:
A textbook that aims to
explain the mathematics
on which data science
depends: linear algebra,
optimization, probability
and statistics. All these
topics are necessary to
understand the
architecture and mode
of operation of neural
network technology.

nodes.title: Aesthetic Measure (1933)
nodes.label: Aesthetic Measure
nodes.author: George David Birkhoff
nodes.synopsis:
This classic book
develops a systematic
approach to measuring
the aesthetic value of
particular classes of
aesthetic objects, (e.g.,
polygonal forms,
ornaments, tilings).
Important aesthetic

nodes.title:
Transformations in
Design: A Formal
Approach to
Stylistic Change
and Innovation in
the Visual Arts (1994)
nodes.label: Transformations in Design
nodes.author: Terry Knight
nodes.synopsis:
A great book that uses
shape grammars as the
underlying model of
computation for
Teaching and Design
Important aesthetic
issues are discussed,
such as the "unity" and
"variety" of formal
elements.
investigating style and
stylistic change in art
and architecture.

nodes.title:
Introduction to the
Theory of
Computation, 3rd Edition (2012)
nodes.label: Introduction to the Theory of Computation
nodes.author: Michael Sipser
nodes.synopsis:
A well-written modern
textbook in theoretical
computer science,
focusing on three
traditionally central
areas: automata,
computability, and time
or space complexity. It
explains the
fundamental capabilities
and limitations of
computers from a
mathematical
perspective.

nodes.title:
Architectural
Geometry (2007)
nodes.label: Architectula Geometry
nodes.author:
Helmut Pottmann,
Andreas Asperl, Michael
Hofer, and Axel Kilian
nodes.synopsis:
A textbook for students
in architecture or
engineering design
covering curves and
surfaces, di!erential
geometry, kinematic
geometry, mesh
processing, and
optimization of shapes.

nodes.title:
Formal Engineering
Design Synthesis (2001)
nodes.label: Formal Engineering Design Synthesis
nodes.author: Erik K. Antonsson and Jonathan Cagan (Editors)
nodes.synopsis:
This book contains a
series of late 1990s
papers on formal
computational methods
for engineering design
synthesis, written by a
number of well known
researchers in the area.

nodes.title: Logicomix: an Epic Search for Truth (2008)
nodes.label: Logicomix
nodes.author: Apostolos Doxiadis
nodes.synopsis: This book is a graphic novel that follows mathematician Bertrand Russell's quest for truth. The story, presented as a lecture about Russell's life, intertwines personal struggles, historical events, and mathematical concepts in a captivating exploration of the pursuit of logical certainty.

nodes.title:
Coleridge on
Imagination (1960)
nodes.label: Coleridge on Imagination
nodes.author: I.A. Richards
nodes.synopsis:
A book on literary
criticism and aesthetic
theory which, among
other great things, it
contains one of the best
analysis of Coleridge's
distinction between
"fancy" and
"imagination".

nodes.title: The Four Pillars of Geometry (2005)
nodes.label: The Four Pillars of Geometry
nodes.author: John Stillwell
nodes.synopsis:
An introductory
textbook in geometry
that aims to show how
the subject can be
developed in four
fundamentally different
ways: Euclid-style
constructions, linear
algebra, projective
geometry, and
transformation groups.

nodes.title: Cognitive Psychology and Its Implications, 6th Edition (2004)
nodes.label: Cognitive Psychology and Its Implications
nodes.author: John R. Anderson
nodes.synopsis: This book explores key cognitive processes and their real-world applications. It provides concise insights into memory, problem-solving, and decision-making, making it a valuable resource for students and professionals in various fields.

nodes.title: Part & Whole
nodes.label: Part & Whole
nodes.author: J. Koenderink
nodes.synopsis: This book examines how individual components shape our perception of the whole and vice versa. It explores this relationship across disciplines, challenging conventional ideas and emphasizing its profound impact on our understanding of the world.

nodes.title: The Design of Everyday Things (1988)
nodes.label: Design of Everyday Things
nodes.author: Donald A. Norman
nodes.synopsis: This book highlights user-centered design principles for creating intuitive and user-friendly products. With real-world examples, he emphasizes the significance of thoughtful design in enhancing user experience and usability.

nodes.title: Aesthetics of the Familiar: Everyday Life and World-Making (2017)
nodes.label: Aesthetics of the Familiar
nodes.author: Yuriko Saito
nodes.synopsis: This book redefines aesthetics,emphasizing the beauty within everyday life. The book encourages readers to see the profound aesthetic value in ordinary elements, advocating for a broader perspective on what constitutes the richness of our daily experiences.

nodes.title:
Beyond Price: Value in Culture, Economics, and the
Arts. (2008)
nodes.label: Beyond Price
nodes.author: Michael Hutter and David Throsby
nodes.synopsis: This book explores the multifaceted nature of value in culture and the arts, challenging the notion that value is solely economic. The authors highlight the interplay between intrinsic, social, and symbolic values in cultural goods, emphasizing the importance of recognizing and preserving cultural richness beyond monetary considerations.

nodes.title: What Makes Things (2017)
nodes.label: What Makes Things
nodes.author: Derek Thompson
nodes.synopsis: This book decodes the psychology behind successful ideas and trends, unraveling the factors that transform the ordinary into the extraordinary in our interconnected world.

nodes.title: On Painting and Sculpture (1972)
nodes.label: On Painting and Sculpture
nodes.author: Leon B. Alberti
nodes.synopsis: This book shapes Renaissance art by emphasizing the fusion of creativity and geometry, introducing istoria for narrative depth. The treatise underscores the artist's dual role as both a creative talent and skilled craftsman

nodes.title: Ugliness and Judgment: On Architecture in the Public Eye (2019)
nodes.label: Ugliness and Judgment
nodes.author: Timothy Hyde
nodes.synopsis: This book redefines architectural beauty, examining its impact on public perception. Through historical and modern examples, Hyde challenges preconceptions, prompting readers to reflect on the subjective nature of architectural aesthetics and the societal influences shaping our urban spaces.

nodes.title: A Philosopher Looks at Architecture (2021)
nodes.label: A Philosopher Looks at Architecture
nodes.author: Paul Guyer
nodes.synopsis: This book examines how philosophy influences our perception of built environments, encouraging readers to reconsider the deep connections between philosophy and contemporary architectural thinking.

nodes.title:
Algorithmic Aesthetics: Computer Models for Criticism and
Design in the Arts (1978)
nodes.label: Algorithmic Aesthetics
nodes.author: George Stiny and James Gips
nodes.synopsis: This book introduces a groundbreaking perspective on art, treating designs as algorithms. The book advocates for merging computational thinking with artistic creativity, revolutionizing the relationship between technology and art.

nodes.title: Shape of Imagination: Calculating in Coleridge’s Magical Realm (2022)
nodes.label: Shapes of Imagination
nodes.author: George Stiny
nodes.synopsis: This book probes the synergy between imagination and calculation in Coleridge's literary realm. The book unravels how Coleridge fuses poetic creativity with mathematical processes, offering a unique perspective on the interplay between art and science during the Romantic era.

nodes.title: Classical and Non-Classical Computation (1976)
nodes.label: Classical and Non-Classical Computation
nodes.author: Terry Knight and George Stiny
nodes.synopsis: This book explores conventional and innovative computational models. The authors challenge traditional perspectives, highlighting non-classical approaches and encouraging a broader understanding of computation beyond established norms.

nodes.title: Kindergarten Grammars: Designing with Froebel's Building Gifts (2017)
nodes.label: Kindergarten Grammars
nodes.author: George Stiny
nodes.synopsis: This book explores the application of Friedrich Froebel's building gifts in design. Stiny draws connections between Froebel's educational philosophy and contemporary design principles, emphasizing the importance of play and exploration in shaping creative thinking.

nodes.title: The Logic of Architecture: Design, Computation, and Cognition (1990)
nodes.label: The Logic of Architecture
nodes.author: William J. Mitchell
nodes.synopsis: This book explores the integration of computation and cognition in design. It emphasizes the transformative role of technology, particularly computer-aided design, in shaping and augmenting architectural creativity.

nodes.title: Mathematics and Architecture Since 1960 (2002)
nodes.label: Mathematics and Architecture Since 1960
nodes.author: Lionel March
nodes.synopsis: This book examines the profound influence of mathematical principles and computational tools on architectural design during this period. Through case studies, it highlights the dynamic interplay between mathematics and architecture, revealing transformative impacts on aesthetics, form, and structure.

nodes.title: Structure in Drawings and the Hidden-Surface Problem. (1973)
nodes.label: Structure in Drawings
nodes.author: Ivan Sutherland
nodes.synopsis: This book introduces a hierarchical approach to represent 3D objects and innovative algorithms to tackle the hidden-surface problem in computer graphics. This significantly influences the field, shaping how virtual environments are constructed and viewed.

nodes.title: Computing Machinery and Intelligence. (1950)
nodes.label: Computing Machinery and Intelligence
nodes.author: Alan M. Turing
nodes.synopsis: This introduces the Turing Test, a pivotal concept in artificial intelligence. Turing explores whether machines can display human-like intelligence, presenting a thought experiment involving a judge interacting with a hidden computer and a human. The paper remains influential, sparking ongoing debates on machine intelligence and its implications for our understanding of human cognition.

nodes.title: Problem-Solving Machines (1950)
nodes.label: Problem-Solving Machines
nodes.author: Allan Newell and Herbert Simon
nodes.synopsis: This book lays the groundwork for artificial intelligence, proposing the concept of universal problem-solving machines. This influential work shapes the trajectory of AI development by advocating for computer programs that emulate human problem-solving processes.

nodes.title:
Computer Science as Empirical Inquiry: Symbols and
Search. (1976)
nodes.label: Computer Science as Empirical Inquiry
nodes.author: Allan Newell and Herbert Simon
nodes.synopsis: This influential work, often referred to as the "Symbols and Search" paper, is not a book but rather a significant contribution to the literature on artificial intelligence and computer science. In it, Newell and Simon articulate a comprehensive framework for understanding computer science as a field of empirical inquiry, focusing on the role of symbols in computation and the processes of search and problem-solving.

nodes.title: Steps Towards Artificial Intelligence (1960)
nodes.label: Steps Towards Artificial Intelligence
nodes.author: Marvin Minsky
nodes.synopsis: This paper is considered one of the foundational works in the field of artificial intelligence. In it, Minsky discusses various problems that AI needs to solve to advance, including learning, problem-solving, and the representation of knowledge. He also outlines a vision for future research directions in AI, many of which have guided the development of the field.

nodes.title: Artificial Intelligence, A Modern Approach, 4th Edition (2020)
nodes.label: Artificial Intelligence
nodes.author: Stuart Russell and Peter Norvig,
nodes.synopsis: This book is widely regarded as the leading textbook in the field of artificial intelligence. The 4th edition updates the comprehensive and authoritative content from previous editions, incorporating the latest developments and research in AI. Covering a broad range of AI topics, the book provides in-depth information on problem-solving, knowledge representation, planning, machine learning, natural language processing, robotics, and much more, making it an essential resource for students, researchers, and practitioners in artificial intelligence and related fields.

nodes.title: Necessary Conditions of Learning (2014)
nodes.label: Necessary Conditions of Learning
nodes.author: Ference Marton
nodes.synopsis: This book presents a comprehensive overview of the theory of learning from a phenomenographic perspective, which Marton himself significantly contributed to developing. The book discusses the conditions that are necessary for learning to occur, emphasizing the importance of how different people perceive and understand various phenomena and concepts. Marton's work is crucial in the field of educational psychology and pedagogy, offering insights into how educators can design more effective teaching strategies that cater to the diverse ways students experience and make sense of the world around them.

nodes.title:
The Closed World: Computers and the Politics of Discourse in Cold War
America (1996)
nodes.label: The Closed World
nodes.author: Paul N. Edwards
nodes.synopsis: This book explores the relationship between the development of computing technology and the political and military strategies of the Cold War era in the United States. Edwards examines how computers became symbolic and practical tools within the national security state, influencing both the conduct of the Cold War and the broader cultural understanding of computing in society. Through a detailed historical analysis, the book reveals how the ideologies of the Cold War were embedded in the development of computing and how these technologies, in turn, shaped political discourse and thought during this period.

nodes.title: The End of Programming (2023)
nodes.label: The End of Programming
nodes.author: Matt Welsh
nodes.synopsis: This explores the evolving landscape of coding, highlighting how automation, AI, and low-code platforms are reshaping the role of programmers. He envisions a future where programming becomes more abstract and accessible, transforming the nature of work in the digital age.

nodes.title: Deep Learning (2016)
nodes.label: Deep Learning
nodes.author: Ian Goodfellow, Yoshua Bengio and Aaron Courville
nodes.synopsis: This is a  fundamental guide by Goodfellow, Bengio, and Courville, offering a concise overview of neural networks and their applications, suitable for both beginners and experts in the field.

nodes.title: What is ChatGPT Doing... and Why Does It Work? (2023)
nodes.label: What is ChatGPT Doing?
nodes.author: Stephen Wolfram
nodes.synopsis: In this short book, prominent scientist and computation pioneer Stephen Wolfram provides a readable and engaging explanation that draws on his decades-long unique experience at the frontiers of science and technology. Find out how the success of ChatGPT brings together the latest neural net technology with foundational questions about language and human thought posed by Aristotle more than two thousand years ago.

nodes.title: Engineering Knowledge: The Construction of Knowledge in Artificial Intelligence (1993)
nodes.label: Construction of Knowledge in Artificial Intelligence
nodes.author: Diana E. Forsythe
nodes.synopsis: This book delves into the interplay between engineering practices and cultural influences in shaping AI knowledge, offering concise insights into the dynamic relationship between technical expertise and societal factors in the field of artificial intelligence.

nodes.title:
Architectural Intelligence: How Designers and Architects Created the
Digital Landscape (2017)
nodes.label: Architectural Intelligence
nodes.author: Molly Wright Steenson
nodes.synopsis: This explores the symbiotic relationship between architecture and technology, tracing the evolution of digital design and its impact on our modern digital landscape.

nodes.title: Machine Learning: Architecture in the Age of Artificial Intelligence (2022)
nodes.label: Architecture in the Age of AI
nodes.author: Phil Bernstein
nodes.synopsis: This explores how AI is revolutionizing architecture, blending human creativity with computational capabilities for innovative design solutions.

nodes.title: The Age of AI: And Our Human Future (2021)
nodes.label: The Age of AI
nodes.author: Henry Kissinger, Eric Schmidt and Daniel Huttenlocher
nodes.synopsis: In The Age of AI, three leading thinkers have come together to consider how AI will change our relationships with knowledge, politics, and the societies in which we live.

nodes.title: Builders of the Vision: Software and the imagination of Design (2015)
nodes.label: Builders of the Vision
nodes.author: Daniel Cardoso Llach
nodes.synopsis:
A history of Computer-
Aided Design and Numerical Control since
the years following WWII
until today, with original
archival work on
research on CAD
developed at MIT
between 1949 and 1970.

nodes.title:
Architectural
Morphology: Introduction to the Geometry of Building Plans (1983)
nodes.label: Architectural Morphology
nodes.author: Philip Steadman
nodes.synopsis:
This book is about a
research area called
"configurational studies"
of architectural form. It
is mainly concerned with
the possibility of using
finite combinatorial
geometry to describe
and enumerate possible
forms which buildings
and their plans may
take.

nodes.title: Building Types and Built Forms (2014)
nodes.label: Building Types and Built Forms
nodes.author: Philip Steadman
nodes.synopsis: This book offers an analysis of the relationships between building types (categories of buildings defined by their uses and functions) and their built forms (the physical shapes and structures of those buildings). Steadman combines theoretical discussions with practical analyses, providing insights into the evolution and variation of building forms over time.

nodes.title: The Society of Mind (1986)
nodes.label: The Society of Mind
nodes.author: Marvin Minsky
nodes.synopsis: This book is about answering the question "How Does the Mind Work?". Minsky portrays the mind as a "society" of tiny interacting components that are themselves mindless.

nodes.title: Thoery and Design in the First Machine Age
nodes.label: Design in the First Machine Age
nodes.author: Reyner Banham
nodes.synopsis: Focusing on the modernist movement, this book explores how industrialization influenced architects like Le Corbusier, Gropius, and van der Rohe. It delves into the interplay between technological advancements and design theory, highlighting the era's innovative approaches to integrating mechanization into architecture and design. It is one of the well-known books on what is known as rationalism.

nodes.title: The Alphabet and the Algorithm
nodes.label: Alphabet and the Algorithm
nodes.author: Mario Carpo
nodes.synopsis: Examines the impact of digital technology on architectural design. Carpo explores the transition from a culture based on the written word (the alphabet) to one influenced by numerical computation (the algorithm). The book discusses how digital tools and algorithms have transformed the architectural design process, challenging traditional modes of representation and conception. Carpo explores the implications of this shift in the context of architecture and design history, offering insights into the evolving relationship between technology and the built environment.

nodes.title: Notes on the Synthesis of Form
nodes.label: Notes on the Synthesis of Form
nodes.author: Christopher Alexander
nodes.synopsis: One of the first theoretical books on architecture that employs mathematics for the description of functions satisfying specific human needs. The mathematics are based mainly on set theory and are fully developed in a long appendix. Another appendix demonstrates the application of the method to the design of an Indian village. In this book, Alexander makes an important distinction between traditional un-self-conscious cultures and our own self-conscious culture of professionally or academically educated designers.

nodes.title: Design by Optimization in Architecture, Building, and Construction
nodes.label: Design by Optimization
nodes.author: Antony D. Radford and John S. Gero
nodes.synopsis: A comprehensive exploration of applying optimization techniques in architectural design. The book covers fundamental optimization concepts, such as the notion of a design space and its exploration, and includes practical applications in architectural projects, and case studies. An important resource for anyone that wishes to delve deeper into the relationship of design and mathematical optimization.

nodes.title: The Geometry of Environment: An Introduction to Spatial Organization in Design
nodes.label: The Geometry of Environment
nodes.author: Lionel March and Philip Steadman
nodes.synopsis: In the 1970s, the revolution in the teaching of new mathematics and the advent of the computer in design challenge traditional ways of appreciating the space about us, and expand the ‘structural’ understanding of our surroundings through such concepts as transformations, symmetry groups, sets and graphs. This book aims to show the relevance of this new maths and encourages exploration of the widening intellectual horizons of environmental design and architecture.
